subject: Re: How to test protected and private methods/ fields?

messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Dan North <dan@c...> wrote:
> In response to Nic's specific example, I would suggest this is
crying out
> for a Strategy design pattern. In this case, the algorithm and any
> refinements would be represented by their own class and would
therefore be
> testable in their own right.

I found this comment (and Ilja's, who made essentially the same point)
quite interesting. Two issues come up, though.

First, the Strategy Pattern buys you some flexibility at the cost of
some added complexity. You could read the principle of YAGNI as
saying don't pay for the flexibility until you know you need it. If I
don't have any real reason to believe that I'm likely to swap in a new
algorithm later, then moving the algorithm into its own class could be
seen as overkill. (There are still, however, plenty of reasons to
encapsulate it in its own method, like readability and coherence.)
Moving it into its own class does buy you something in simplifying the
testing, though, so is that (up-front, immediate) benefit sufficient
to justify the cost of the pattern?

The other issue is that there's probably some sort of spectrum here,
with little tiny methods on the one hand and big complex algorithms on
the other. The tiny methods can probably be private and not directly
tested (although that's not entirely obvious), and the big guys
probably can/should be pulled out into their own classes. In between,
though, it would seem that there are (private, helper) methods that
aren't big enough to justify their own class, but are still big enough
that you'd want to test them independently.

Nic
